This evening all users in our Blackboard Connect system will be receiving an all-call and an e-mail regarding reopening surveys. We have assembled Reopening Task Force Teams that have already started to difficult task of examining every aspect of our operation in preparation for resuming, in some capacity, this fall.

We have created three surveys. One for parents and guardians, one for 6th-12th grade students, and one for faculty members. The surveys will be used to help the Task Force Teams make decisions about the capacity in which we can reopen.

The parent/guardian and student surveys will be sent via e-mail, will be available on the website, and paper copies will be available at the Board Offices. The surveys do require student ID numbers to maintain authenticity. We ask that the surveys are returned electronically or in the drop-box outside the Board offices no later than Friday, June 12.

While many more questions than answers remain, we appreciate your input and cooperation. Be well, stay safe, and as always GO BLACK TIGERS!

Tiger One for All is a collection of links and online resources collected to one webpage by the Media Specialists and Classroom Technology Integration Specialists for the purpose of sharing basic ideas, methods and safety concerns when using tech for education.

This is a resource for all of our community as we continue through this period of “stay at home” orders for the sake of the health of our community.

For more information go to bit.ly/tigerone4all. For a richer explanation of Tiger One for All, click on the podcast at the bottom of the page for CFHS student DJ’s interview with Alex Oris, Computer Technology Integration Specialist at Bolich and Roberts Middle Schools.

Please Note: this is Not the website for specific curriculum and classroom assignments; parents should login to Progressbook or Google Classroom for that materials as it applies to your student.

Frequently asked questions:

Why does the levy amount appear on the 1st half 2019 tax bill that was just received?

When a levy is passed in a calendar year, it is applied to the entire calendar year in which the levy is approved by the voters and collection begins in the subsequent calendar year.

In this case, the levy passed in November 2019 is applied to the entire calendar year 2019 and collection begins in 2020 which is why the levy appears on current tax bills.

Specifically, real property taxes are paid in January and July of the calendar year following the tax year (TY) for which the taxes are levied. Thus, the county treasurer will collect the first half of TY ’19 real property taxes in January 2020. Collection of the second half of TY ’19 collections will occur in July 2020.

We hope this has been helpful. For more information, visit the county auditor's website:

http://fiscaloffice.summitoh.net/index.php/tbe

Frequently asked questions:

What will be the effect on busing? Will the district need to purchase new buses to accommodate transporting students from other areas?

• Yes, we will have to make adjustments in transportation. While state law only mandates transportation outside a two-mile radius for students in grades K-8, we have no intention to transport a 6th grade student while leaving his/her 10th grade sibling behind. Succinctly, we intend to provide transportation for students in grades 9-12 as well.

• We will examine the application of state law with addition of high school ridership and make necessary adjustments for safety and efficiency.

• As a result, by state law, we will need to offer transportation to students attending non-public schools within a thirty-minute radius of the public building which the student would normally attend unless it is declared impractical based on criteria provided in law.

• How many buses is under investigation; however, we are estimating four to five additional buses.

Frequently asked questions:
Why renovation v. new buildings? Why not just renovate the existing buildings?

• Based on assessments of our buildings, renovating buildings to current construction and OFCC standards which include energy efficiency, life safety, security, classroom size, technology, etc. will cost more than two-thirds (67%) the cost to build new.

• Once a building crosses the two-thirds threshold, it is recommended to build new buildings such that we can get the most efficiency from our investment:
• For example, Bolich = 81% Roberts = 76% CFHS = 76%

• In new buildings, we can design spaces that best meet the educational needs of our staff and students in a 21st century learning environment.

Black Tiger Family,

We have seen posts regarding our district calendar; in particular, the mid-August start date. We have been on the same schedule for at least three years. For example, our Convocation Day was August 14 kicking off the 2017-18 school year. Similarly, Convocation Day was August 13 last year. The BOE adopted calendar for next year, 2020-2021, has Convocation Day on August 17.

Members of the Six-District Educational Compact start on or about the same date. This year, Kent is a week later based on their needs and Tallmadge starts August 22 due to construction.

The calendar has shifted over the last few years due to testing and to get the first semester done before Winter Break. The semester break then aligns with our university partners for the sake of College Credit Plus courses.

As a result of the shift, the school year is complete prior to Memorial Day. We hope this helps explain the reasons why the start date of school has shifted for many districts over the last few years.

Have a great day!
